Issues.Title: ngcc tries reading schematic "package.json" files
Issues.Body:
Currently in our `cli-hello-world-ivy` integration test:

```
Failed to read entry point info from /home/circleci/ng/integration/cli-hello-world-ivy/node_modules/@schematics/angular/workspace/files/package.json with error SyntaxError: Unexpected token < in JSON at position 1121.
```

It looks like this happens because ngcc just tries to read all `package.json` files and `@schematics/angular` ships their templated `package.json` file without using the `.template` suffix.

I suspect the real fix would be that `@schematics/angular` just uses the `.template` suffix for their templated files, so that ngcc does not even try to read it.

We can move this issue to the CLI if @petebacondarwin thinks that this is the right solution, but I've submitted it here to see if there is something ngcc needs to handle differently.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "ngcc tries reading schematic "package.json" files" (#27950)

Issues.Title: *ngIf/For as a TemplateRef might cause troubles
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report

### Affected Package
@angular/core

### Is this a regression?
Don't think so/Don't know

### Description
Apparently, because *ngIf, and *ngFor (for example) are treated as TemplateRefs this markup

```
<ng-container *ngIf="true" mycontainer>
    This shouldn't be considered a Template, IMHO
</ng-container>

<ng-template>
    Right Template
</ng-template>
```

Used by a component that wraps it and uses it like this:

//Should get the ng-container tagged as "mycontainer"
<ng-content select="[mycontainer]"></ng-content>

//Should get the ng-template element
<ng-template [ngTemplateOutlet]="templateRef"></ng-template>

Where "templateRef" is retrieved with ContentChild like this:

Will end up printing in the HTML the sentence "This shouldn't be considered a Template, IMHO" twice.
The fact that items tagged with *ngIf *ngFor are considered templates is extremely confusing. It took me a miracle to figure out that could be the problem in my application.

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): sanitization for Host Bindings
Issues.Body:
This PR adds sanitization for `elementProperty` and `elementAttribute` instructions used in `hostBindings` function, similar to what we already have in the `template` function.

Main difference is the fact that for some attributes (like "href" and "src") we can't define which SecurityContext they belong to (URL vs RESOURCE_URL) in Compiler, since information in Directive selector may not be enough to calculate it. In order to resolve the problem, Compiler injects slightly different sanitization function which accepts tag name and property name and detects proper Security Context at runtime.

This PR resolves FW-785.

Issues.Title: Micro Frontends, Using angular framework as externals
Issues.Body:
We are trying to split the a big front-end application (app.mydomain.com) into 2 smaller applications
1. Pre-Login application (prelogin.mydomain.com) - This includes everything before the user logs in
2. Post-Login application (postlogin.mydomain.com) - This includes everything after the user logs in

Both of these applications use angular framework which is currently being bundled along with other java-script files. Since angular framework is quite big in size, this increases the bundle size and hence impacts the frontend page loading performance. 

Since both of these micro applications are using the angular framework, we don't want to reload angular for second time (when user switches from prelogin to postlogin). Instead, we want to load angular as a external script from third domain (third.mydomain.com) and cache it in browser for future uses. Hence, when user switches from prelogin to postlogin, instead of loading the bundle again, a cached angular bundle from browser will be used.

I could not find anything in Official angular documentation which talks about loading angular in HTML (as a external script). Is this something which angular supports? Does angular provides a UMD module?

Regards,
Manav

Issues.Title: Dot segments from path not removed
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report

### Affected Package
@angular/router

### Is this a regression?
No

### Description
By RFC3986 (https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3986#page-33) dot segments should be removed from path.

When accessing `localhost:4200/segment/./segment` by browser navigator, browser strips the dot segments and Angular router recieves `localhost:4200/segment/segment`. Everything works as expected.

When programmatically routing to `'./segment/./segment'`, Angular throws an error (404).
Browser navigator still shows URI with dot segments *stripped* (`localhost:4200/segment/segment`).

### Versions
<!--
Output from: `node --version`, `npm --version` and `ng --version`.
  Windows (7/8/10). Linux (incl. distribution). macOS (El Capitan? Sierra? High Sierra?)
-->


### Repro steps
```
ng new repro-app
ng add @angular/pwa
ng build --prod --baseHref /coolapp/
```


### The log given by the failure
No failure log. 
But the ngsw.json has the following output:
```
...
"navigationUrls": [
    {
      "positive": true,
      "regex": "^\\/.*$"
    },
    {
      "positive": false,
      "regex": "^\\/(?:.+\\/)?[^/]*\\.[^/]*$"
    },
    {
      "positive": false,
      "regex": "^\\/(?:.+\\/)?[^/]*__[^/]*$"
    },
    {
      "positive": false,
      "regex": "^\\/(?:.+\\/)?[^/]*__[^/]*\\/.*$"
    }
  ]
...
```

### Desired functionality
The service worker should be scoped to the baseHref location provided in the `ng build` command. 
This way other resources on the same domain can still be loaded without beeing interfeered by the service worker. 

The desired ngsw.json would be:
```
...
"navigationUrls": [
    {
      "positive": true,
      "regex": "^\\/coolapp\\/.*$"
    },
    {
      "positive": false,
      "regex": "^\\/(?:.+\\/)?[^/]*\\.[^/]*$"
    },
    {
      "positive": false,
      "regex": "^\\/de\\/ \\/(?:.+\\/)?[^/]*__[^/]*$"
    },
    {
      "positive": false,
      "regex": "^\\/de\\/ \\/(?:.+\\/)?[^/]*__[^/]*\\/.*$"
    }
  ]
...
```


### Mention any other details that might be useful
My Use Case:
We have an app that is shipped in multiple languages. Every language is served under a different path, e.g.:
```
https://coolapp.com/en/
https://coolapp.com/de/
```
When changing the language both service workers do collide in their responsibility, as both match their pattern: 
```
    {
      "positive": true,
      "regex": "^\\/.*$"
    }
```
and want to serve their `index.html`. By scoping them to their respective location on the server they do not collide anymore. 

### Workaround (nasty)
Define different `"ngswConfigPath": "src/ngsw-config.json"` (full duplicates) in your `angular.json` for each environment and specify the `navigationUrls` accordingly:
```
"navigationUrls": [
    "/de/**",
    "!/**/*.*",
    "! /**/*__*",
    "! /**/*__*/**"
  ]
```

### Desired functionality
<!--
What would like to see implemented?
What is the usecase?
-->
The default `"target"` in `tsconfig.json` generated by `ng new` should be `"es6"`, not `"es5"`.

Reasons:
1. Modern browsers are being optimized for ES6 now. ES5 is no longer necessary or optimal.
2. Smaller generated code files.
3. Fewer problems out-of-the box (without having to use flags that new users might not know about), e.g. https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript/issues/3164 

I understand this is a judgement call, and there could be reasons I don't know about to keep the default as es5. If so, I'd like to hear what those are, since I believe it is better to move forward. Apps that have to support Internet Explorer already need to include some polyfills, and I think they're in the minority, so the default should cater to the majority -- users that really *should* be targeting ES6, and may not even think to change the settings in their `tsconfig.json` file.

Issues.Title: Allow interacted field of matStep in the stepper control to be editable via property binding
Issues.Body:
#### Please describe the feature you would like to request.

The interacted field of the matStep (https://material.angular.io/components/stepper/api) is currently not decorated with @Input() therefore it is not possible to use property binding to modify it.

#### What is the use-case or motivation for this proposal?

Calling the Stepper Previous() or Next() method ends up calling "CdkStepper.prototype._anyControlsInvalidOrPending" where there is a check for "!step.interacted". I have a use case where I populate the steps and then set a particular step as the selected step.  At that point when I call next or previous since the steps interacted field is false by default I'm not able to go backward or forward through the stepper.  

At the moment my only way to solve this issue is to iterate the stepper's "_steps" and set the "interacted" field to true.  This is not an ideal solution.

#### Is there anything else we should know?

Version: 7.2.0
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Allow interacted field of matStep in the stepper control to be editable via property binding" (#14724)
